title: How to find my true self if consciousness cannot be seen by the mind - Quora

response.answer_text: You can’t “find your true self’, regardless of whether or not consciousness can be seen by the mind. True self isn’t in there waiting to be discovered — it emerges as your relationship with truth evolves. One way to say that — brief but somewhat punchy — is “true self gives birth to itself.” So there’s no point in looking for it buried away inside you: you won’t find it. That doesn’t mean that introspection or self-observation are pointless: there are plenty of truths that can be uncovered by turning on the bright lights of self-awareness… it’s just a mistake to mark any of those truths as “my self.” The self you can discover is always some derived concept: you take out your knife, and you cut around something that seems like an edge or a boundary between “this” and “that”, and you designate “this” as “self”, and now you’ve got a self-concept. It doesn’t matter what provides the boundary, anything you choose will yield the same result semantically — “some definition of I which was produced by discrimination and semantic designation.” That includes “enlightened” ideas like “the self is consciousness” or “the self is non-dual awareness”, as well as traditional ideas like “the self is your values” or “the self is your inner love”, etc. There is no way to construct a definition of self which doesn’t rely on this bit about discrimination and designation, and in general those processes occur in a way which “disowns” the resulting definition — in other words, the individual treats their self-definition as if it were a pre-existing truth that they have discovered, rather than a meaning which they created. That’s “disownership”: failing to acknowledge ones’ authorship of a distinction or concept. So is “true self” even an authentic possibility? My answer is an unequivocal “yes”. Absolutely, it’s an authentic possibility. But… a “disowned meaning of self” is inherently inauthentic, according to me. If you have a definition of self which you didn’t create, then I call “bullshit.” You’ve disowned your knife of discrimination — you’re acting as if there’s some external authority which blesses the meaning you give to “I”… like the laws of meaning, or God, or some famous philosopher or something. But no such authority can be found and authenticated. So then does that mean you’re free to just make up any old definition of “self” as long as you acknowledge your authorship? Nope! Can’t get away with that one, either… because if you (for example) try to make up the idea that you are Napoleon Bonaparte, you run into the problem of “it’s your word vs. a huge pile of facts.” There’s a ton of facts which validate the conventional meaning of “Napoleon Bonaparte”, and if you want to co-opt the meaning of “Napoleon Bonaparte” and give it a different meaning than what convention offers, you’re going to have to dismiss a huge pile of facts. The meaning of “Napoleon Bonaparte” isn’t naturally in your domain of authority: you can redefine it, but doing so won’t give you any deep truth that you can stand upon. This conversation can go on for quite a while: a complete treatment of all of the “logic of meaning” that surrounds the topic of true self is a lengthy conversation. So I want to zip past a lot of that and share how this turns out, if done correctly: there is a domain of meaning in which you are an absolute authority, and that domain has limits. Within those limits, you have no competition: you have complete power to make truth, and the truth you make is just as true as any other truth. But, making that kind of truth is entirely optional: nothing will make this kind of truth for you, if you don’t make it. The space just stays empty if you don’t fill it. What you get by being human is the possibility of true self, but not the actuality. To “actualize” true self requires giving birth to yourself — you have to realize that the potential exists, that you already have the power that you need, but that power must be exercised — and then you are 100% responsible for the maintenance of the truth that you create: you create it ongoingly, in effect. The domain of authority that a human naturally has is the power to create “transcendent truth” about the self. A “transcendent” truth is a truth which is not “boxed up” by opposition to other kinds of truth. An example of a transcendent truth is “I am whole and valid.” This truth is true because I have the authority to make it true, and my designation of that as a truth is entirely grounded by my willingness to stand for it and uphold it. This truth is not in opposition to any other truth, it provides a context or “frame” for other truths, but doesn’t argue with them, as would happen if I claimed to be Napoleon Bonaparte. So I create that truth and then I relate to that truth as something which I can express, and a sort of “validation loop” occurs between the results of my self-expression and the truthfulness of the truth I’ve created… my willingness to put myself on the line to uphold that truth results in actions which demonstrate that it is, in fact, true. I am indeed whole and valid, and my actions and feelings and thoughts validate that. But to keep that straight, I must be willing to hold my own authority as absolute in this domain — I can’t rely on anybody else validating my authority, nor can I allow others to “outrank” me in this domain. It is entirely my job to say what “I” means: I can make and validate and uphold transcendent truths about that, and when doing so, I become “self-grounding”, and then I know what true self is — not just as an abstract concept, but as a lived experience that affects my life in profound ways. Sorry, that’s kind of a long treatment of the topic, even though it leaves out a lot. It might be obvious that this viewpoint disagrees with all other viewpoints about the meaning of “true self”, since it relies on a pretty careful path through the subject of ‘self’ and ‘truth’, but I stand by the claim that all of its competitors can be slain with counter-arguments. This one will remain standing in any storm.

Since the body, mind and soul are one composite unit - who you are is the ultimate reality (permanent) and what you are in body and mind is the mid-reality (temporary). Now in the mid reality, you remain in illusions presuming the thinking self to be that true self. Once, you go beyond the mind, you discover your true self. The actual self or the ultimate reality cannot be seen but can definitely be observed by your superconscious section, which is considered by science as the unconscious part of the brain. How? When you are alert and aware, you will observe that there is another self seated in the mind checking, guiding and warning your thinking self; whenever it tries to do something unfavourable or when crossing a certain limit, warning- you should not. This subtle inner voice is that true self, which cannot be seen but can be felt. Spiritualism refers to that as the soul and the role it plays in the mind is that of the witnessing consciousness. Whenever, you are alert, observant, attentive and aware you shall discover that inner witnessing self, guiding you now and then whenever required. So long as your desires do not suppress refusing to listen to that divine residing within - Thou Art That. giankumar.com
